awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Systemic Signaling Networks in Arabidopsis
awd_abstract_narration:
Stresses such as herbivore or pathogen attack can severely limit plant growth and development, for example, by reducing crop production and impacting food security around the World. Plants possess natural sensory systems that allow them to detect these stresses and then mount defenses against them. Defining how these response systems operate is therefore important in both understanding how plants survive and thrive in the natural world and how to effectively capitalize on these innate responses to improve the resilience of agriculture. Recent research has made key advances in characterizing these signaling systems within the plant, revealing that plants deploy an internal biochemical communication system that broadcasts stress information from its site of perception to the rest of the plant body. This information then triggers the production of defenses such as the accumulation of toxic chemicals, priming even the non-attacked parts of the plant for defense. This communication system operates quickly, spreading information throughout the plant over the course of minutes. Despite such a central role in coordinating each plant’s rapid stress responses, the cellular components that trigger this system and then transmit the stress signal throughout the plant remain poorly defined. This project will focus on characterizing the role of two major cellular messengers, the calcium ion and reactive oxygen species, in propagating these rapid stress signals. The investigation will also explore how amino acids released by the plant may act as initial triggers for this response. This work will train graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to help prepare them for their future careers in research and science. The project will also provide public education on plant stress responses and provide training to students in effective science communication.

Recent studies have revealed a rapid systemic signaling system in plants mediated through Ca2+- and reactive oxygen species-dependent events. This research program seeks to extend our understanding of these processes to the levels of the channels and tissue architectures that support this signaling network. The Arabidopsis thaliana Glutamate-Like Receptor (GLR) channels and reactive oxygen species-producing NADPH oxidases have been linked to this rapid systemic propagation of Ca2+-based signals. Therefore, this study will focus on defining the role(s) of these proteins in systemic transmission of local wound, pathogen elicitor (flg22) and salt stresses. The specific aims are to: (1) compare the patterns of Ca2+ and ROS signaling that occur during the initiation and propagation of long-distance signals in response to these stimuli and define the spatial and temporal characteristics of the channels and ROS-related enzymes supporting these activities; and (2) explore how glutamate and other amino acid signals are involved in triggering these long-distance signals. These goals will be accomplished using a combination of bioreporter imaging and mutant and molecular analyses. This study will reveal new insight into the molecular machinery underlying rapid plant systemic signaling. The project will help define the spatial and temporal changes in calcium and reactive oxygen species that relay information about stresses throughout the plant. The research will also help define whether information about each stress is likely encoded in specific signaling dynamics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project, "Collaborative Research: Systemics Signaling Networks in Arabidopsis," was focused on understanding how calcium and reactive oxygen species signals occur and interact during the initiation and propagation of long-distance signals in response to various environmental stimuli such as salt stress, wounding, and pathogen elicitors. It also attempted to dissect the underlying molecular components of these cellular signals. Through the research activities, we have created a new ratiometric calcium-detecting biosensor, which was an essential tool for our discoveries because the ratiometric calcium biosensor named CGf allowed us to detect real-time calcium changes in live plants from single cells such as pollen and whole plant levels under different environmental stress conditions. Additionally, we have utilized genetic materials involved in reactive oxygen species synthesis and scavenging during stress responses to understand the correlation between stress-triggered calcium and reactive oxygen species signals.

Using the new ratiometric calcium biosensor and genetic materials involved in reactive oxygen species pathways, we have obtained multiple outcomes, as briefly summarized below;

Systemic signaling during flooding in plants: We have found that calcium signaling is triggered by flooding stress and low oxygen stress. In particular, local flooding stress to the root triggers systemic shoot responses characterized by the upregulation of genes associated with shifts in primary metabolism and calcium homeostasis, such as the calcium transporter CAX2, the vacuolar membrane-localized calcium, and the proton exchanger. We have found that knockout mutant of CAX2 exhibit bigger flooding/low oxygen stress-triggered calcium increase at the flooded root regions with no systemic cellular signal transmission to non-flooded distal shoots compared to control wild-type plants, suggesting CAX2 is involved in flooding stress-triggered long-distance calcium signaling propagation. These findings indicate that the flooding-triggered local calcium and systemic calcium signals are essential for coordinating the root-to-shoot communication and adapting to flooding-induced low oxygen stress.

Heat Stress-triggered Calcium Signaling: Using our ratiometric calcium biosensor CGf, we revealed that heat stress-triggered cytosolic calcium signaling occurs in the whole aerial part of plants within 30 minutes of exposure to the heat. For example, cytosolic calcium increased and peaked within 5 minutes after exposure to the heat when air temperature reached a maximum of 40 degrees Celsius. Although heat stress-triggered cytosolic calcium signaling occurred early heat stress, no further calcium changes occurred even though the air temperature was maintained around 40 degrees Celsius for 3 hours. However, single-cell-sized tissues in heat stress-responding leaves showed different heat stress-triggered calcium signaling patterns than whole leaves, suggesting that population analyses of stress-related signaling may not represent local and single-cell responses under the same stress conditions, such as heat. These findings were possible due to our ratiometric calcium biosensor CGf, which has the capacity to detect kinetics and biological functions of stress-related calcium signals under various stress conditions.

ROS-assisted wound-induced rapid systemic calcium wave in roots: We have found wound-triggered long-distance calcium signaling propagation in the roots and the impacts of ROS accumulation on systemic calcium waves in the roots. When roots were subject to mechanical wounding, wounding-triggered systemic calcium signals were rapidly transmitted to entire plants in wild-type plants. However, the wound-triggered systemic calcium signaling propagation was impaired in reactive oxygen species synthesis and scavenge-related mutants, rbohD and OxAPEX2, showing more than 3-fold slower systemic calcium waves transmission through the root vasculature than wild-type. Thus, the RbohD and APEX2-dependent attenuation of systemic calcium signaling propagation supports a model in which ROS signals initiated outside the cell by RbohD need to be decoded inside the cell for wound-triggered long-distance calcium waves in the roots.

 

Calcium signal-induced ferroptosis-like programmed cell death during fungal pathogen infection in rice:  We have found fungal pathogen-triggered calcium signals, a key signal to prime reactive oxygen species production and iron release from internal organelles. These pathogen-triggered calcium signals resulted in ferroptosis-like programmed cell death in rice during early pathogen infection. Ferroptosis in plant research is relatively new and has not been established. Thus, this finding of calcium signal-induced ferroptosis during pathogen infection in rice is considered an important starting point to expand our understanding of the biological roles of stress-triggered cellular calcium signals in plants. These findings encourage us to continue research if this ferroptosis-like phenomenon is present in other stress responses and if calcium signals are also critical for the ferroptosis-like process. This research was possible by creating transgenic rice plants expressing ratiometric calcium biosensors. These transgenic rice plants are currently being distributed to the scientific community upon request.

The research findings obtained above also lead us to understand that resting calcium levels before and after encountering various environmental stresses are not ubiquitous, indicating that maintenance of cytosolic basal calcium levels is essential for stress response and recovery during the post-stress period, which is one of many critical discoveries made throughout this research activities and is our next target to expand our calcium signaling research further.
